title: A Gentle Practice of Gratitude
intro: A soft, unforced gratitude meditation focused on small, real moments — not pressure, not perfection.
body:
Hi.

Take a moment to settle.
You don’t need to feel grateful for everything.
You don’t need to force a bright mood.
This is not that kind of gratitude.

This is simply a gentle noticing.
A quiet practice of letting small goodness be seen.

If it feels okay, let your body relax a little.
Feel the support beneath you.
Notice your breath moving in and out.

Now, instead of searching for something huge, look for something small.
Something that asked very little of you.
Something simple and real.

It might be the feeling of warmth from a cup of tea.
A blanket.
The way the light looks on a wall.
A message you received.
A moment of quiet.
A shower.
Clean water.
A deep breath.
Even the fact that you made it through today.

Choose one small thing.
And let it be enough.

Bring it to mind.
Not like a checklist.
More like you’re holding it in your hands.

And notice what it feels like to acknowledge it.
Maybe nothing changes.
Maybe you feel a slight softening.
Maybe a tiny lift.
Or maybe you just feel neutral.
All of that is okay.

Now, gently, see if you can name why this small thing mattered.
Not in a grand way.
Just honestly.

Maybe it gave you comfort.
Maybe it gave you a pause.
Maybe it made life easier for a moment.
Maybe it reminded you that you’re cared for.

Take one slow breath in.
And as you breathe out, let your body register:
“Yes. This helped.”

Now, if you want, find one more small thing.
Something different.
Something you can appreciate without pressure.

It could even be a neutral thing that you’re choosing to notice.
The steadiness of the floor.
The presence of a chair.
The fact that your lungs are working.
The fact that you’re here.

Bring it close.
And let it land.

Sometimes gratitude is not a feeling.
Sometimes it’s a practice of attention.
A way of saying:
“I’m willing to see what’s still here.”

If today has been hard, you don’t need to pretend it wasn’t.
Hard days deserve honesty.

So if you need to, you can include this too:
“I’m grateful I survived today.”
Or:
“I’m grateful I’m still trying.”
Or:
“I’m grateful I found one small moment to breathe.”

Now take a final slow inhale.
And a slow exhale.

Let gratitude be gentle.
Let it be small.
Let it be real.

And when you’re ready, return your attention to the room.
To your body.
To this moment.

Thank you for practicing.
You can come back to this anytime — especially when it’s hard.
